trans-unit.source: Add Mobile Services to an existing universal Windows app | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Add Mobile Services to an existing universal Windows app | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to connect your existing universal Windows app to Azure Mobile Services.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to connect your existing universal Windows app to Azure Mobile Services.

trans-unit.source: This topic shows you how to use Azure Mobile Services to leverage data in a universal Windows app.
trans-unit.target: This topic shows you how to use Azure Mobile Services to leverage data in a universal Windows app.

trans-unit.source: Universal Windows app solutions include projects for both Windows Store 8.1 and Windows Phone Store 8.1 apps and a common shared project.
trans-unit.target: Universal Windows app solutions include projects for both Windows Store 8.1 and Windows Phone Store 8.1 apps and a common shared project.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <linkText>Build universal Windows apps that target Windows and Windows Phone</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <linkText>Build universal Windows apps that target Windows and Windows Phone</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial, you will download a Visual Studio 2013 project for a universal Windows app that stores data in memory, create a new mobile service, integrate the mobile service with the app, and then sign-in to the Azure Management Portal to view changes to data made when running the app.
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial, you will download a Visual Studio 2013 project for a universal Windows app that stores data in memory, create a new mobile service, integrate the mobile service with the app, and then sign-in to the Azure Management Portal to view changes to data made when running the app.

trans-unit.source: This topic shows you how to use the tooling in Visual Studio Professional 2013 with Update 3 to connect a new mobile service to a universal Windows app.
trans-unit.target: This topic shows you how to use the tooling in Visual Studio Professional 2013 with Update 3 to connect a new mobile service to a universal Windows app.

trans-unit.source: The same steps can be used to connect a mobile service to a Windows Store or Windows Phone Store 8.1 app.
trans-unit.target: The same steps can be used to connect a mobile service to a Windows Store or Windows Phone Store 8.1 app.

trans-unit.source: To connect a mobile service to an Windows Phone 8.0 or Windows Phone Silverlight 8.1 app, see <linkText>Get started with data for Windows Phone</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: To connect a mobile service to an Windows Phone 8.0 or Windows Phone Silverlight 8.1 app, see <linkText>Get started with data for Windows Phone</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: To complete this tutorial, you need the following:
trans-unit.target: To complete this tutorial, you need the following:

trans-unit.source: An active Azure account.
trans-unit.target: An active Azure account.

trans-unit.source: If you don't have an account, you can create a free trial account in just a couple of minutes.
trans-unit.target: If you don't have an account, you can create a free trial account in just a couple of minutes.

trans-unit.source: For details, see <linkText>Azure Free Trial</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For details, see <linkText>Azure Free Trial</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Visual Studio Express 2013 for Windows</linkText><title></title> (Update 2 or a later version).
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Visual Studio Express 2013 for Windows</linkText><title></title> (Update 2 or a later version).

trans-unit.source: 7.
trans-unit.target: 7.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, open the App.xaml.cs code file in the GetStartedWithData.Shared project folder, and notice the new static field that was added to the App class inside a Windows Store app conditional compilation block, which looks like the following example:
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, open the App.xaml.cs code file in the GetStartedWithData.Shared project folder, and notice the new static field that was added to the App class inside a Windows Store app conditional compilation block, which looks like the following example:

trans-unit.source: This code provides access to your new mobile service in your app by using an instance of the [MobileServiceClient] class.
trans-unit.target: This code provides access to your new mobile service in your app by using an instance of the [MobileServiceClient] class.

trans-unit.source: The client is created by supplying the URI and the application key of the new mobile service.
trans-unit.target: The client is created by supplying the URI and the application key of the new mobile service.

trans-unit.source: This static field is available to all pages in your app.
trans-unit.target: This static field is available to all pages in your app.

trans-unit.source: 8.
trans-unit.target: 8.

trans-unit.source: Right-click the Windows Phone app project, click Add, click Connected Service..., select the mobile service that you just created, and then click OK.
trans-unit.target: Right-click the Windows Phone app project, click Add, click Connected Service..., select the mobile service that you just created, and then click OK.

trans-unit.source: The same code is added to the shared App.xaml.cs file, but this time within a Windows Phone app conditional compilation block.
trans-unit.target: The same code is added to the shared App.xaml.cs file, but this time within a Windows Phone app conditional compilation block.

trans-unit.source: At this point, both the Windows Store and Windows Phone Store apps are connected to the new mobile service.
trans-unit.target: At this point, both the Windows Store and Windows Phone Store apps are connected to the new mobile service.

trans-unit.source: The next step is to create a new TodoItem table in the mobile service.
trans-unit.target: The next step is to create a new TodoItem table in the mobile service.

trans-unit.source: Now we can test both versions of the universal Windows app against the mobile service hosted in Azure.
trans-unit.target: Now we can test both versions of the universal Windows app against the mobile service hosted in Azure.

trans-unit.source: 4.
trans-unit.target: 4.

trans-unit.source: In the [Azure Management Portal], click Mobile Services, and then click your mobile service.
trans-unit.target: In the [Azure Management Portal], click Mobile Services, and then click your mobile service.

trans-unit.source: 5.
trans-unit.target: 5.

trans-unit.source: Click the Data > Browse and notice that the TodoItem table now contains data, with id values generated by Mobile Services, and that columns have been automatically added to the table to match the TodoItem class in the app.
trans-unit.target: Click the Data > Browse and notice that the TodoItem table now contains data, with id values generated by Mobile Services, and that columns have been automatically added to the table to match the TodoItem class in the app.

trans-unit.source: This concludes the tutorial.
trans-unit.target: This concludes the tutorial.

trans-unit.source: This tutorial demonstrated the basics of enabling a universal Windows app to work with data in Mobile Services.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial demonstrated the basics of enabling a universal Windows app to work with data in Mobile Services.

trans-unit.source: Next, consider reading up on one of these other topics:
trans-unit.target: Next, consider reading up on one of these other topics:

trans-unit.target:

trans-unit.target:
